title: Federal Excise Tax on Beer Could Triple

content: Did you people read the same article I did? quote: Madison - The last time Wisconsin's beer tax was raised, Neil Armstrong was walking on the moon. But now's the time for another increase, Rep. Terese Berceau (D-Madison) said Wednesday. She's asking lawmakers to consider supporting a bill to take the beer tax from $2 a barrel of beer to $10 a barrel, which means an increase of about 2 1/2 cents a bottle. "Wisconsin has a drinking problem of national renown that is killing people and ruining lives, and government in Wisconsin has been an enabler," Berceau said at a Capitol news conference with co-sponsor Sen. Fred Risser (D-Madison), law enforcement and health care professionals. Risser noted that he's the only state legislator who was in office in 1969, when the last beer tax increase became law. The proposal is unlikely to become law. Gov. Jim Doyle opposes it, and similar proposals in the past have died for lack of support. Wisconsin's tax is the country's third lowest, and the state has one of the highest rates of binge drinking and drunken driving crashes, supporters said. The state also has high alcohol-related health care costs, they said. Now is the wrong time to even consider such a tax increase, said Scott Stenger, lobbyist for the Tavern League of Wisconsin, which opposes the beer tax increase. Taverns are seeing a significant decline in business because of the ongoing financial slump, he said. The proposed beer tax increase would bring in about $40 million in new revenue a year, according to figures on Berceau's Web site. The new funds would go toward increased drunken driving enforcement and alcohol abuse prevention and treatment.
quote: Madison - The last time Wisconsin's beer tax was raised, Neil Armstrong was walking on the moon. But now's the time for another increase, Rep. Terese Berceau (D-Madison) said Wednesday. She's asking lawmakers to consider supporting a bill to take the beer tax from $2 a barrel of beer to $10 a barrel, which means an increase of about 2 1/2 cents a bottle. "Wisconsin has a drinking problem of national renown that is killing people and ruining lives, and government in Wisconsin has been an enabler," Berceau said at a Capitol news conference with co-sponsor Sen. Fred Risser (D-Madison), law enforcement and health care professionals. Risser noted that he's the only state legislator who was in office in 1969, when the last beer tax increase became law. The proposal is unlikely to become law. Gov. Jim Doyle opposes it, and similar proposals in the past have died for lack of support. Wisconsin's tax is the country's third lowest, and the state has one of the highest rates of binge drinking and drunken driving crashes, supporters said. The state also has high alcohol-related health care costs, they said. Now is the wrong time to even consider such a tax increase, said Scott Stenger, lobbyist for the Tavern League of Wisconsin, which opposes the beer tax increase. Taverns are seeing a significant decline in business because of the ongoing financial slump, he said. The proposed beer tax increase would bring in about $40 million in new revenue a year, according to figures on Berceau's Web site. The new funds would go toward increased drunken driving enforcement and alcohol abuse prevention and treatment.
reply: Did you people read the same article I did?
title: Federal Excise Tax on Beer Could Triple

content: "http://www.dailytribune.com/articles/2009/05/24/news/doc4a18c885867e7277344073.txt" quote: WASHINGTON — A federal soda pop tax. Higher levies on beer, wine and hard liquor. Taxing some health insurance benefits. Those are among the options the Senate is considering to pay for revamping health care. quote: Potential revenue raisers also include doing away with flexible spending accounts, limiting the income tax deduction for out-of-pocket medical costs, and charging upper income seniors more for their Medicare drug plans. quote: Rep. Charles Rangel, chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, said Congress “absolutely” has the will to raise taxes to pay for health care reform.
quote: WASHINGTON — A federal soda pop tax. Higher levies on beer, wine and hard liquor. Taxing some health insurance benefits. Those are among the options the Senate is considering to pay for revamping health care.

I know now it let us sleep good and the grown-ups could go on visiting. Still tickles me to this day to know that.
quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: quote: Originally posted by charlie_echo: Applejack sound pretty good right about now! LOL...for what, your lawn mower??
reply: Oh, no sir, my nana and momma could make it just right. When we were kids, the highpoint of the family gatherings, was getting to have a cup before bed. I know now it let us sleep good and the grown-ups could go on visiting. Still tickles me to this day to know that.
title: Federal Excise Tax on Beer Could Triple

content: We must stand up and fight. We must storm the steps of the Capital. Tar and Feather those in politics who are dishonest. (which is 81% of them). I strongly believe the next terror attack in this country will be from a fed up American. Why should Al-Qaeda even want to hit us again when all they have to do is wait us out because we are doing a very good job of destroying ourselves.
reply: We must stand up and fight. We must storm the steps of the Capital. Tar and Feather those in politics who are dishonest. (which is 81% of them). content: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: We must stand up and fight. We must storm the steps of the Capital. Tar and Feather those in politics who are dishonest. (which is 81% of them). I strongly believe the next terror attack in this country will be from a fed up American. Why should Al-Qaeda even want to hit us again when all they have to do is wait us out because we are doing a very good job of destroying ourselves. It depends, one more 9/11 style attack and it will throw this nation over the cliff politically and socially. It would confirm Dick Cheneys greatest fears, and validate the administration of President Bush. I do not wish to see something like that happen again, but I do not have any illusions about the safety of our nation under liberal control either. Until the blue half of our nation realizes we do not live in a utopian paradise where rainbows and flowers appear out of thin air, only then will we be safe... Someone, somewhere is plotting and planning....
